title: Ask HN: How common are wireless devices without an FCC ID
text: Got some fans on prime day and I decided I'd like to control them with an SDR. I went to look up the FCC ID to get the frequency and realized there were no markings on the remote inside or out. Even the microcontroller has no markings at all. After looking for it with the SDR it was on 434Mhz (not 433). Is this normal now?

title: Ask HN: What are examples of companies with a great culture?
text: I'm looking for a new job which got me thinking; which companies have/had the best cultures? What makes somewhere a great place to work? Are there examples of companies known for a great culture which changed or degraded over time?

title: Show HN: Fide – Crunchbase for Web3 Projects and People
text:
Hi HN! I’m Chris, Co-founder of Fide. When contracting for Celsius in 2019, a recently bankrupt crypto-lending platform, I quickly observed how important it was for every Web3 company to establish credibility and trust in a high-risk industry where fraud and scams are becoming increasingly common.

As I continued to invest and build in the space, it became clear that existing tools are still not enough to effectively evaluate credibility. Common issues that keep coming up include: 1. Repeat scammers are rarely held accountable 2. Anonymous contributors can’t easily establish credibility 3. Project and contributor success metrics are mostly based on historic financial performance

We built Fide to help users verify web3 credibility and only invest in projects and teams they can trust. We’re still adding features and projects but would welcome any feedback as we continue building!

Ask HN: Foreign language learners, what's the workflow you find most effective?
text:
My initial exposure to English was through video games. Then as a fifth-grader, I was sent to a private language school where I had group classes with other kids. However, being a kid as I was, I was never aware that the time would come when I would get to use what I learned in real life - otherwise, I would have invested a lot more energy into it. Now that I'm late in my 20s, I have a crystal-clear idea of why knowing a foreign language - such as English - is paramount. Hence, I want to put a more coordinated effort into studying languages.

Do you use applications (for example, Duolingo or, perhaps, some other less gamified app), or do you resort to more traditional methods such as group classes where you get to improve everything from speaking to listening to reading and writing?

How do you improve every aspect of your language skill (reading, listening, speaking, writing)?

What do you use for translating unfamiliar words and improving your vocabulary? Do you use wordlists?

Do you practice spaced repetition? Do you make your own flashcards?

Feel free to describe your workflow and the tools you use.

Ask HN: Do any of you do any replay testing in a microservices environment?
text:
Replay testing is when you replay production requests into your testing environment and compare corresponding responses for variances. It's a way to do regression testing that's a bit more black boxy but might end up being more comprehensive than your hand written test suite.

I have heard other companies do this, but haven't found good blog posts about how and what are the potential pitfalls. Especially in a microservices environment where there could be many data dependencies, so doing this kind of testing might be harder.
